DataElement.preferredName: Pancreatic Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 Pathologic Tumor T Stage
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Extent of the primary exocrine and endocrine pancreatic cancer based on evidence obtained from pathologic examination through completion of definitive surgery.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A non-encapsulated elongated and lobulated organ, extending from the concavity of the duodenum to the spleen; it consists of a head, an elongated body, and a tail. It contains two functional components: an exocrine component that secretes juices into the intestine and an endocrine component that secretes hormones (insulin and glucagon)._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology._One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A non-encapsulated elongated and lobulated organ, extending from the concavity of the duodenum to the spleen; it consists of a head, an elongated body, and a tail. It contains two functional components: an exocrine component that secretes juices into the intestine and an endocrine component that secretes hormones (insulin and glucagon).:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Concepts.definition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: Pathologic; caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.:One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

Concepts.definition: Caused by or altered by or manifesting disease or pathology.
One criteria of the TNM staging system. T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 9/13/17 tt transferred context; changed Reg Status to Qualified. Created for CRF standard harmonization. Released per final community approval. mc 5/15/12

ValueDomain.preferredName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) Edition 7 T Stage
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A finding about one or more characteristics of exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (including carcinoid tumors) are now staged by a single pancreatic staging system. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)_A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._One criteria of the TMN staging system.  T refers to the extent of tumor involvement at the primary site (T, followed by a number indicating size and depth of invasion)._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT0 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT0 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with no evidence of primary tumor. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT0 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with no evidence of primary tumor. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT1 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT1 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with tumor limited to the pancreas, measuring 2 cm or less in greatest dimension.. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT1 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with tumor limited to the pancreas, measuring 2 cm or less in greatest dimension.. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with tumor limited to the pancreas, measuring more than 2 cm in greatest dimension. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT2 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with tumor limited to the pancreas, measuring more than 2 cm in greatest dimension. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with tumor extending beyond the pancreas but without involvement of the celiac axis or the superior mesenteric artery. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT3 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with tumor extending beyond the pancreas but without involvement of the celiac axis or the superior mesenteric artery. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT4 TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT4 TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with tumor involving the celiac axis or the superior mesenteric artery (unresectable primary tumor). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pT4 TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with tumor involving the celiac axis or the superior mesenteric artery (unresectable primary tumor). (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pTis TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pTis TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with a finding of carcinoma in situ.  This also includes the PanIn III classification.  (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pTis TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer with a finding of carcinoma in situ.  This also includes the PanIn III classification.  (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pTX TNM Finding v7

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pTX TNM Finding v7
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.longName: Exocrine and Endocrine Pancreatic Cancer pTX TNM Finding v7
Concepts.definition: Exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer in which the primary tumor cannot be assessed. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

Concepts.definition: A finding about one or more characteristics of exocrine or endocrine pancreatic cancer, following the rules of the TNM AJCC v7 classification system.  Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (including carcinoid tumors) are now staged by a single pancreatic staging system. (from AJCC 7th Ed.)

The extent of a cancer in the body.
